title: Tax when your company sells assets

details.description: Your company may have to pay Corporation Tax if it sells an asset for more than it paid. The profit is known as a 'chargeable gain'
details.alternative_title: Tax when your company sells assets ('chargeable gains')
details.body:
If your company sells or disposes of an asset for more than it cost, it may have to pay tax on the ‘gain’.

Assets are things your company owns, eg:

  • land and property
  • equipment and machinery
  • shares

You may have to treat gains on ‘intangible assets’ (eg intellectual property) as business income if your company acquired them or they came into existence after 1 April 2002.

Working out the gain

  1. Work out the asset’s value when it was sold - either the amount of money your company received or the market value of the asset (if it was given away or sold for more or less than it was worth).

  2. Take away the  amount your company paid for the asset - if it was bought for more or less than it was worth, use the market value at the time.

  3. Take away any money your company spent buying, selling or improving the asset, eg solicitors fees, Stamp Duty, the cost  of a loan to pay for the asset etc. You can’t claim maintenance costs.

  4. Work out the value of the asset at today’s prices by using HM Revenue and Customs’ (HMRC) Indexation Allowance. Download the Indexation Allowance table for the month when you sold the asset and then use the figure for the month when the asset was bought. If any improvements were made, work out the effects of inflation in the same way.

You can check whether your valuation of an asset is correct by filling in a valuation form (PDF, 200KB) and sending it to your Corporation Tax office.

Example - working out the gain

Step Result
1. How much your company got for the asset £200,000
2. Subtract the amount your company bought it for (£120,000) £200,000 - £120,000 = £80,000
3. Subtract any fees, Stamp duty etc from when it was bought (£10,000) £80,000 - £10,000 = £70,000
4. Find the inflation factor for the month it was bought in 0.5
5. Calculate the indexation allowance - multiply the amount it was bought for by the inflation factor £120,000 x 0.5 = £60,000
6. Take away the indexation allowance from the profit £70,000 - £60,000 = £10,000
Gain £10,000

The Indexation  Allowance means that there’ll be no gain unless the value of an asset  has gone up by more than the inflation rate.

If you personally sell or dispose of assets you’ve taken out of a company, you may have to pay Capital Gains Tax if you make a gain.
